DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to determine whether a standardised osteopathic manipulative treatment is more effective on 3 months functional recovery than a placebo of osteopathic manipulative treatment, in sub-acute and chronic low back pain less than 1 year duration.
DOC.brief_title: Comparison of the Effectiveness of 2 Manual Therapies Administered by Osteopaths on Functional Outcome in Sub-acute and Chronic Low Back Pain
DOC.detailed_description: Sub-acute (4-12 weeks duration) and chronic (more than 3 months duration) low back pain (LBP) is frequent, disabling and costly. The effectiveness of usual treatments (including pain killers, anti-inflammatory drugs, spinal infiltrations, physiotherapy, spinal traction, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, etc) may be not sufficient, and many patients resort to alternative therapies. Manipulative treatments represent en emerging therapy in this area, although studies assessing their effectiveness are limited and often biased. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of two manual therapies administered by osteopaths on improving functional recovery in sub-acute and chronic low back pain less than 1 year. A standardised osteopathic manipulative treatment is compare to a placebo of osteopathic manipulative treatment.
DOC.criteria: Patient consulting for back pain Male or female aged from 18 to 65 years (included) Subacute or chronic low back pain Patient can speak and understand French Patient giving his informed consent to participate in the study Patient affiliated to or beneficiary of social insurance Back pain caused by: inflammatory, tumoral, infectious disease or a back traumatism in the 3 past months Back surgery and/or fracture in the 6 past months Presence of a motor impairment related to the reason for consultation Chronic low back pain more than 1 year duration (for the current episode) The patient is a student or a practitioner in manipulative therapies Pregnancy Inability to understand the process of the study The patient is already included in another clinical study
